title: Are Ballet Sneakers the Next Big Footwear Wave?
article_text: All products featured on GQ are independently selected by our editors. However, we may receive compensation from retailers and/or from purchases of products through these links. Predicting the next big wave insneakersis always a crapshoot. Sure, brands can put millions of dollars behind complex marketing pushes for a silhouette, but you can’t force a shoe style to stick. Sometimes atrend rises with no rhyme or reason, or because theright celebrity wore the right shoe at the right time, or because hype fatigue heightens demand fora simple pair of black and white kicksyou can throw on with any outfit. We’ve spent the last couple of months calling out therise of the granddad shoeas an indicator as to where the culture is going, but some interesting stats suggest another major movement in the scene is upon us: against all odds, it’s ballet sneaker season. To clarify, we don’t mean you need to go pick up a pair of satinballet flatsto stay up these days (though we’d never stop you–lace those ribbons up if you feel the urge). Rather, we’re seeing the rise of a style of sneaker that draws heavy inspiration from the pared-down construction of ballet shoes. These are kicks with slim uppers that conform to your foot, often an accentuated arch support, and a thin sole. Think of them as the aesthetic inverse of dad shoes, if not quite mom shoes themselves. The shoe at the center of the trend is the aptly-named Ballerina by Adidas andBad Bunny. An original silhouette that blends the Adidas Taekwondo with some tweaks drawing from ballet flats, it proved an instant success in a way we haven’t seen yet since the superstar first collaborated with adidas. Anything with Benito’s name on it (these literally do, emblazoned on the side) tends to sell out pretty quickly, but there was a unique fervor around the Ballerina and its three launch colorways (two neutrals in black and white and a gold rendition heavy on theBruce Leevibes). Trends don’t always come down to which shoes celebrities wear but it certainly doesn’t hurt for one of the biggest stars in the world to give ballet sneakers such a substantial seal of approval. Adidas StockX Adidas StockX Speaking of the Taekwondo, it’s benefiting from the moment as well. While this silhouette was originally designed as a shoe for, you guessed it, taekwondo, the aesthetic similarities between it and ballet sneakers are strong. From a functional standpoint they largely serve the same purpose as ballet shoes (support stemming from a shoe that molds to your foot and keeps your sole low to the ground), plus what is taekwondo if not ballet for boys? The Stripes have leaned into the similarities with a pared-down incarnation of the Taekwondo called the Mei Ballet. It features an upper that bares most of the top of your foot to a lengthy lace window and long enough laces to provide ankle support as well. Adidas isn’t the sole brand in the ballet sneaker game, though.PumaandOnitsuka Tigerhave both leaned into it, both offering ballet-friendly versions of classic silhouettes in the Speedcat Ballet and Mexico 66 Ballet. Both trim down the uppers of reliable favorites and replace laces with straps. They’re exclusively available in women’s sizing, but personally we’d advise to never let something like that stop you from getting on the wave. It’s also worth noting that the Puma Speedcat itself has been wildly popular over the last year. While it’s not a ballet shoe (its origins are in motorsport) it shares the same sense of design and minimalism as ballet shoes, speaking to a broader desire in the scene for simpler, slimmer silhouettes these days. Other brands are incorporating the influence of ballet shoes into silhouettes in more off-kilter ways.Salomon, for example, in a collaboration withSandy Liangreplaced the traditional lace system of the Speedcross 3 with a thick ribbon, getting in on the ballet moment without creating a shoe that strays too far from the aesthetic they’ve cultivated over the years. PUMA Foot Locker Salomon StockX Don’t take our word for it, though–the numbers don’t lie here. Regardless of your opinion on the resale market as an industry, StockX remains one of the most valuable hubs of trend data in the sneaker world. They recently reported that between February and March (around the time of the Bad Bunny Ballerina drop), sales of shoes featuring “ballet” or “ballerina” in the name increased well over a whopping 1,000%. That’s a lot of sales of a lot of shoes and certainly enough to warrant calling it to attention. Trends are trends and there’s no telling if ballet sneakers are just having a moment or having a year. We won’t know until we get there. In any case, it’s a refreshing moment in a sneaker scene that’s been spinning its wheels over the same retros and reheated nachos over the last few years. Ballet sneakers are slim, sexy, and fun. They offer the chance to incorporate a style of sneaker that might be seen as traditionally feminine into more menswear-centric fits. They won’t bite. They’re far from gatekept and you don’t have to audition forSwan Lakefor the right to lace up a pair.

title: 9 Best Back Shavers of 2025, Tried & Tested
article_text: All products featured on GQ are independently selected by our editors. However, we may receive compensation from retailers and/or from purchases of products through these links. If there's one thing to remember when hunting for the best back shaver, it's that there’s no shame in having a hairy back. In fact, more power to you if you rock asweater’sworth of fuzz without a care in the world; we could all learn something from ya. And you know who else can learn something? The guy whoDIYsa hasty solution to get rid of his back hair and ends up withredness,ingrown hairs, or a shoddy half-shorn finish. For this guy, we’re here to first and foremost recommend the best back shaver,trimmer, ormanual razor, which makesback hair removala one-man task. (Later on, we’ve got some best practices on how to put your newly acquired electric back hair shaver to use.) Let’s get to it. Philips Norelco Amazon Key features:Dual-function trimming and foil shaving head; three body-trimming guards (3, 5, and 7mm); detachable and extendable rubber grip; waterproof| Battery:Rechargeable; 1-hour charge; 1-hour runtime Why we love it:Name one category of body grooming devices that Philips Norelco doesn’t absolutely dominate. This brand has your back—and literally, in this case. Their 5000 series body groomer brings dual-action efficiency to the thickest thatches, with each hair getting chopped down by the trimming teeth, then mowed over by the foil head shaver. It is a great manscaper for your front and back half, but for the back specifically, I love its clip-in extendable handle that bends to whichever degree you need. I do like this one as abody hair trimmertoo—it’s adept for that, but prefer it as an actual shaver, especially on the backside. (I don’t know many guys who “trim” their back hairs to anything but a barely-there 0.1mm.) So just go bare-guarded with this and shear it all off. If you do want a dual body hair trimmer/shaver from the brand, I suggest upgrading to the dual-endedBodygroom 7000. But when it comes to straightforward back hair handling—especially for the solo shaver who doesn’t have a helping hand from his +1 or roommate—the less expensive and equally adept 5000 series is unbeatable. BaKblade Amazon Key features:Wide blades designed for wet or dry shaving; rubber-grip foldable handle; detachable exfoliating brush Why we love it:This one looks all kinds of funny—maybe it could catch a pop fly before it clears the outfield fence, or maybe it’s an ancient torture device. When put to the test of shaving the back, though, this one truly is a home run. Its nearly two-foot-long handle allows you to hold it high up over your shoulder and down to the lower back. Its widerazorscover enough real estate to do the entire task in a few simple minutes, too. My first time out, I wondered if it would really hit every spot, with no irritation or redness. And yet every time I have used the BakBlade, I get the same smooth results, no matter how long I’ve let my hair grow out. The one trick I have is an odd raised mole on the one side of my back (I have had it looked at, yes); I’m anxious to just glide this one over top that mole, so I do have to deploy some extra strategy in that section of the back—typically, just taking it slow with this same BakBlade is more than enough to get the results I want and need. I’ve become a BakBlade evangelist—my texts are riddled with friends bragging about no longer having to ask their partner or roommate for help. The BakBlade does go through razors fast, since it uses three (sigh, proprietary) blades at once, and only includes three when you purchase. I suggest bundling in an extra dozenblade replacements, which should get you six months or so of smoothness. Gillete Amazon Key features:5 blades; flexible head navigates contours; double lubrication strips to reduce skin irritation Why we love it:If you’re committed to shaving your back with the same cartridge-style razor as your cheeks (dealer’s choice on which “cheeks” I mean), then I’d happily endorse this manscaping sensation from Gillette. It’s built for your fragile, awkwardly shaped junk, which is why I trust it to navigate the blindspots on my back. (I like to apply the same thinking to my skincare and shaving: When in doubt, buy the product that’s built for the sensitive stuff.) I often ask my partner to shave my back for me, too, especially ahead of a long beach-sprawling week, and that’s when I want to deploy something that allows for this kind of precision and sensitivity, packaged into one. As for self shaving: While the Gillette doesn’t let me reach every square inch of my back like I can with the electric and expandable options, it’s a terrific solution for battling wooly collar creep: shoulder-level shaves and upper-back cleanups. Be sure tostock up on some extra cartridges, too. Amazon Key features:Two swappable shock-absorbing heads (trimmer and foil shaver); extra-wide shaving head and extendable neck; 135-degree trimming angle for perfect clip; power-burst button for added oomph; foldable handle; waterproof| Battery:80-minute runtime on 2.5-hour charge Why we love it:Long before I employed my partner for my back hair maintenance, Mangroomer was a lifesaver. It’s the best electric manscaping option for any combination of shaving and trimming your backside; its two interchangeable heads allow for whichever task you need to tackle. And above all, this foldable and adjustable trimmer gives you full control over your shaving domain—that is, your backside and its many blindspots. My preference is to use it as a dry shaver, since it won’t cut quite as riskily close as an actual manual razor. I’ve never had any issues with nicking or razor burn with the Intellimax Pro’s main trimming head, and honestly, I just leave its trimming head attached. It cuts to a 0.5mm stubble—so short it’s not even stubble—which feels as good as a shave for me (especially considering that it eliminates the threat of razor burn and ingrowns). Panasonic Amazon Key features:Angled vertical trimming head, swappable guard lengths: 3mm, 6mm, and a sensitive-skin “helmet” guard| Battery:Rechargeable; 50-minute runtime; 1-hour charge Why we love it:Panasonic’s all-star manscaper won gold in ourbest body groomerslist for a few years running, for two key reasons. First, Panasonic always delivers serious power and performance. Second—and specific to back hair trimming—its vertical trimming head makes snipping hairs—even from behind your back and over your shoulder—ridiculously easy, skating over hairy skin without any friction or agony. (It does require the slightest flexibility to hit the centermost part of your back, but it’s a trick you’ll master after the first few uses.) This design also makes it great for snipping hairs in odd crevices, like at the top of your haunch, and in the armpits. For back hair mitigation, I prefer to use the bare blade, no guards; I assume the same of you, since leaving short hairs feels against the point. And although I sometimes get a slight red streak due to the proximity of the trim, it never stings and it always disappears within a couple hours. Remington Amazon Walmart Key features:5 rotary panels; slip-proof grip; waterproof| Battery:50 minute runtime on 4-hour charge Why we love it:Lots of guys don’t need a back hair shaver, butdorequire the aid of a good shoulder hair mitigation plan. For that, use the same device that tops our list of thebest bald head shavers: This rotary-faced shaver from Remington hugs every curve of your shoulders, and can intake the coarsest or curliest of hairs without requiring a dozen passes. Plus, if you’re bald, you can just do everything together in the shower, in one single stretch. BroShaver Amazon This manual back shaver has two settings: Mild and Saucy. While the names are a little goofy (and undeniably fun) this unique two-setting approach lets you control how close you want your shave to be. Mangroomer Amazon For seriously hairy backs, we like the power of the Mangroomer Ultimate Pro. It's a personal grooming workhorse, and features Flex Necks that contour your back to help with blade-skin alignment while you trim. BakBlade Amazon With a 23-inch-long handle and six BakBlade refill cartridges so you can actually swap out your blades when you'resupposedto, this device lets you hit every spot on your back for a smooth shave every time. Hatteker Amazon Hatteker makes great budget grooming products—from beard trimmers to hair clippers—and with four removable heads and skin-safe blades, this is no exception. Choosing the right back shaver for you boils down to that classic debate: Manual razor orelectric shaver? You have terrific options for both—including a range of options within each bucket. Manual (razor) back shavers:Like thebest facial razors, back razors shave your hairs slightly below the surface of skin, meaning you get a baby-smooth finish that should last all weekend. You also get all of a blade’s potential downsides:razor burn,razor bumps, and ingrown hairs. The risk is worth the dolphin-esque reward if you have particularly thick hair that grows fast. You can choose from broad-based razors (like that of the BakBlade), or standard cartridge razors (like Gillete’s). I’m typically not one to endorse using a safety razor on your own back, given the blind spots and degree of difficulty navigating your shoulders while risking charlie horses—all while you handle a sharp blade at awkward angles. Remember to stay on top of yourrazor hygieneand swap the blades out after 2-3 weeks of use or after 6-8 shaves (whichever comes first). If you choose a manual razor for your back, be sure to shave it the day or night ahead of any sun exposure so it gets a moment to heal before getting cooked at the beach. Electric back shavers:Like thebest electric shaversfor your face, battery-powered back shavers will cut slightly above the surface of the skin. That means that you might feel the stubble after the first day (though visually, you should look hairless for a few days to a week). If you need an emergency beach day shave, an electric shaver will be faster and prevent double damage to your skin. In my own opinion, it’s worth having an electric back shaver on back-up duty even if you prefer a razor. Most electric back shavers resemble body trimmers because of the ergonomics involved; since so many of these trimmers cut your hair to a smooth finish, I oftentimes consider body trimmers and body shavers as one in the same—and when you open your box, you may find attachments in your body shave to help you with hard-to-reach places. Actual shavers for your back will often have trimming teeth buffering both sides of its foil shaving panel (as used in the Philips Norelco option above). This design allows you to mow through any stray hairs ahead of the shearing blades, and to save time without having to first trim the hairs down with a separate device. Rotary shavers work just fine if you can manage the contortions. (Rotary options are great for the shoulders, in particular, so if that’s the only place you want to shave body hair, don’t bother getting a dedicated back hair trimmer, instead sticking with a rotary shaver.) Properly shaving your back doesn’t have to be complicated, but there are a few things you’re going to want to brush up on before you head to Amazon to stock up on the best clipper and do-it-yourself. Look for an adjustable handle that allows you to reach areas of your back that you might not otherwise be able to (note: some electric razors and beard trimmers have these included when you buy them, so if you have one of those tools you may already be set). Make sure your blade is sharp and that you have replacement blades at hand. And then go easy. “Developingrazor burnis very common when shaving the body, especially when shaving areas you can’t see,” addsDr. Ryan Turner, board-certified NYC dermatologist and co-founder ofTRNR Skin, of how to stay pain free when shaving. “Besidesusing a dull blade, [the act of] dry shaving or shaving too quickly are leading causes of razor burn, and if you can’t see how much shaving cream you’ve applied or fully reach the area, you’re more likely to get razor burn. That lack of visibility can also cause nicks. I’ve seen backs look like the person got in a fight with a cat!” 1. Practice good razor hygiene Less is more when it comes to repeat uses with any back hair razors—specifically with manual razor blades. “We’re addressing a lot of surface area, which is going to dull the razor blade faster, so you don’t want to start with a blade that’s already begun to dull,” says Turner. “It’s optimal to use a fresh razor blade each time you shave your back. The sharper a razor blade is, the smoother the shave. A dull blade will snag on the hair or the skin, increasing your likelihood of causing nicks, cuts, razor burn, or ingrown hairs.” 2. Build out your regimen It’s a good idea to turn this whole process into a proper shave regimen, says Turner, similar to thebest face shaving routine. So, if you aren’t just doing a quick once-over with an electric trimmer, then you should add in a few more steps in order to prevent razor burn, bumps, and ingrown hairs. “Take a shower, then cleanse and exfoliate,” says Turner. “This gets off dirt, debris, and softens the hairs in preparation for shaving.” If you can manage the application (or have a friend to help, he says to use a shave gel to help improve razor glide across the skin. (Score one for using a close-cutting back hair trimmer instead of a bare razor, if you are handling this task on your own.) Then: “Use your fresh razor with gentle, light strokes, rinsing off the razor every few strokes to prevent clogging of the razor so that a smoother shave happens,” Turner advises. “Rinse away hair bits and the shaving products with warm water, pat the skin dry or air dry, and then apply moisturizer.” 3. Test your sensitivities Not all of us have the same sensitivities or reactions to things like shaving, so it’s good to experiment with different trimming and shaving techniques as you decide what works best for you—and never attempt something for the first time if you need a clean backside days later. If you don’t know how your back handles an actual shave (versus a simple trimming), then pre-beach is not the time to try, says Turner. 4. Buffer your buffing by a day Similar to the tip above, you should just never do a shave (or wax) right before you expect to show it off—even if you know your skin tends to handle it well. “Your skin is exposed to a lot of elements at the beach, like sun, sand, wind, and ocean or lake water,” says Turner. “And thus a lot of potential irritants [factor into play]. Shaving can exfoliate a significant amount of the topmost layer of skin, which can negatively affect the skin barrier, your first line of defense against external irritants.” So, giving skin a night or two to recover will help build back this barrier post-shave. “It also helps to properly moisturizing the skin post-shave,” says Turner. “Removing that first layer of skin also makes your skin more susceptible to sun damage, so don’t forget toapply sunscreen!” 5. Trim before you shave If your hair is grown out more than a couple weeks’ worth, then you shouldn’t just go in with a manual razor and expect a smooth shave, Turner says. Ditto if you have really coarse body hairs. You have to trim first, then go in with the actual razor. But again, I suggest simply defaulting to a trimmer in the first place, since they can trim your hairs so close to the skin that itlooksand feels smooth. Sure, that smoothness lasts a day or three, but it’s easy to go in with the trimmer again (and takes a couple minutes, tops), as soon as you need to show it off again. I wish I could tell you that I got professional IPL (laser hair removal), or that I never grew back hair in the first place. Alas, I am as fuzzy as the day is long, and I have needed back hair shavers ever since college. That’s a cool two decades of experience—over half of them spent as a professional grooming expert and product tester—so I have tested pretty much every significant product on this planet, and stay atop the trends with the latest new products to market, too. This list reflects all my favorites across a variety of executions, all resulting in smooth, problem-free skin.

title: The Story Behind Michael B. Jordan’s Sultry Sinners Tank Top
article_text: All products featured on GQ are independently selected by our editors. However, we may receive compensation from retailers and/or from purchases of products through these links. This story contains spoilers forSinners. There are a lot of thoughtful, serious costumes inSinners. DirectorRyan Coogler’s wildly successful, deeply horny, 1930s-set vampire movie is full of period references, fine details, and one ridiculously jackedMichael B. Jordan. And for large swaths of the film, Jordan’s rippling biceps are framed by a ripped, sweaty, bloodytank top. During my screening, the woman next to me muttered a very earnest “Oh mygod”when Smoke—one of Jordan’s twin protagonists—strips down to his ribbed tank and leather gun holsters to fight off the hoard of Irish-jigging vampires in act three. My group chat debrief involved equal amounts of “That was amazing,” and “MBJ fine as hell.” Everyone is reminded ofthat poor girlwho bit clean through her retainer when Jordan took his shirt off inBlack Panther,and everyonegets it. Anyway. I’m getting carried away. The point is: Smoke’s tank top = good. Very good. Ruth E. Carter,Sinners’ Oscar-winning costume designer (who also worked on bothBlack Panthermovies with Coogler), says the choice was all about practicality. Smoke and Stack are army vets. So, Carter and Jordan cycled through a few options before landing on the vest. “Once we got in the fitting room, and we’re trying different ideas about how we would end this movie with Smoke, we knew that there was a military aspect to their story,” says Carter. “Both [Smoke and Stack] served in World War I. I tried on a vintage green army thermal, you know? I thought about what he could have [on] his chest that he could pull out when it was time.” In the end, they went with a less militaristic option—but one that still spoke to Smoke’s pragmatic nature. (This was also the ethos behind the twins’ suits, too: Stack, more of a lothario, sports sharpItalian tailoring, collar pins, and matching pocket squares; Smoke, the everyman, is inworkwear-inspired tailoring, with room to conceal his weapons.) But, of course, there’s no denying the other factor: “Michael B. Jordan is just the most handsome,” says Carter. “He’s so conscious about his health and working out and staying fit… It just made sense that [the tank top is] where we would end up. “More than likely [Smoke] had the tank top on for, you know, someotherreason,” says Carter with a smile. You know: real character stuff. But when you’ve got the rippling biceps of Mr Jordan at your disposal, and blood and sweat to splash on him, you put him in that ribbed tank. Carter says Jordan is a keen collaborator on sets, and they often riff off each other during the fitting process. “He’s not dictating. We’re conversing. He’s excited. We get excited about the possibilities,” she says. “This is the time when we can actually speak our mind in a fitting. It’s a transformation process, and there’s no pressure. There’s not an audience watching you. You’re laughing. You’re playing.” Sadly, we have (semi-) bad news for anyone whose cinema experience left them frantically googling ‘Michael B JordanSinnersvest buy now’ (and maybe also: ‘Michael B Jordan pec routine overnight results’). The tanks aren’t available for mass purchase—they were made in collaboration with California brandRunabout Goods. “We made everything,” says Carter. “That tank top is from a small designer brand that specializes in men's workwear from the ’20s and ’30s, and he manufactures right out of his house. That tank top is based on the cut of a real original tank top that was worn in the ’20s, down to the ribbing style.” If you’re looking to recreate Jordan’s smolderingSinnerslook, you can custom order the tank top through the brand’s website. Sweat, blood, and biceps not included. Merz b. Schwanen Huckberry Gap Gap This story originally appeared onBritish GQ.

title: My Grandfather Is the Most Powerful Dandy I Know
article_text: I prefer to write in my grandfather’s shirt. I’m wearing it now, a blue-and-white-striped Brooks Brothers button-up he passed down to me as a teen. It’s one of several garments I have of his, among them a Christian Diordress shirt, a broadcloth button-down fromBarneys New York’s private label, and a pale pink tie with a diagonal stripe pattern by Oscar de la Renta. I cherish them because they’re his; they express his style. And when I wear that shirt I feel most at home, so to speak. But I also take pride in wearing or simply having his clothes because he’s a Renaissance man. Eight years ago, for the Butler Institute of American Art’s Black History Month programming, my grandfather curated a self-titled exhibition, “Maj. Amos Randall Sr.: Love You Greatly,” which included a self-portrait he drew in elementary school and other illustrations of his own work. (“LOVE YOU GREATLY” is his signature sign-off, even when texting. All caps, always.) As a Vietnam War hero, he was inducted into the Ohio Military Hall of Fame in 2005, receiving numerous awards for his service and leadership. He’s a devoted woodsman. And during the cozily structured summers I’d spent with him—writing essays and book reports for prompts he’d given me, most memorably—he was one of my earliest editors. I texted him last June asking if he still kept stacks of books and newspapers at the foot of his bed. It’s no surprise that he does; his astute, creative, affective word use is present as ever. For what now seems a rather prescient family history project I was working on, I once had him send photos of his clothes. The man’s got taste. Herewith his “ASSORTMENT OF ATTIRE”: feathered Stetson hats, a London Fogtrench coat, his collection of ties mirroring my preference in them—go bold or bust! Not to mention his three or soPierre Cardinboots from when the designer was better known for menswear. He has a fine eye for clothes that he has applied to his art, as seen in another of his self-portraits, all dandy-like in a white, peak-lapel suit and burgundy polka dot tie with a matching pocket square. To paint the full image of my grandfather sporting such clothing would mean including these accessories: cologne and a nice car. Smelling good, like a good haircut, has always been as vital to Black men’s style as our clothes. And his cars were parked in a neighborhood with only three Black families, in Lawton, Oklahoma, where he still lives. When my mom was growing up, he drove “a pearl white 300 ZX with cognac leather interior. Always detailed and nice and clean,” she recalls. By the time she was in high school, “he drove a white Lexus with chrome wheels.” Maj. Randall took pride in all facets of his appearance. Throughout his life, my grandfather has kept that up with the disciplined consistency one expects from an army veteran. “We were always concerned with ironed clothes, crisp clothes, starching our clothes,” Phillip Randall, my grandfather’s brother, tells me. The two were inseparable growing up, sharing personality traits and an appreciation for fine clothing. Recounting how my grandfather’s time in the military informed his style, Uncle Phillip added, “Amos was always neat and pressed. He wanted to have the best look, but not overtly so.” It’s just that “you would expect all that to be in the uniform.” My grandfather is the kind of man who wielded his dandyish flair at will, oscillating between vibrant and reserved expression, but always keeping it classic. The pictures tell it. There’s one of him with his hand on his hip, afro patted to perfection, clad in a black mesh shirt and light blue shorts. In another, he’s dressed in a dagger-collared floral shirt, white flares, and a navy blue blazer, an ensemble his favorite blues artist B.B. King might’ve worn. I think I would characterize his style today as Mister Rogers-meets-Nat “King” Cole. During a Voice of America interview from the mid-’50s, Cole was prompted to speak on his wardrobe. “Do you have any idea what your wardrobe consists of? How many suits and things like that?” the interviewer asked. Though Cole didn’t keep count, he admitted to preferring “conservative, gray and black and, you know, dark blue suits.” He was the version of a dandy Monica Miller describes as “tastefully reserved” in her monographSlaves to Fashion: Black Dandyism and the Styling of Black Diasporic Identity. I could say the same about my grandfather. He’d wear his three-piece, stone gray, zoot-style suit by Giovanni Testi with a smoothness—the “easy grace that floats around the body like smoke,” as put by Lloyd Boston in his bookMen of Color: Fashion, History and Fundamentals (1998). But, using Cole as an example, Lloyd makes a point much bigger than the clothes, or music, for that matter. “Nat ‘King’ Cole’s barrier-breaking style influence was so powerful that it resonated throughout more areas of Black male culture than just music: The reality of a Black man whose lifestyle was equal to that of any other mainstream public figure was incredibly inspiring.” As a recent high school graduate, Grandfather left Youngstown, Ohio, for basic training down South. Uncle Phillip remembers getting a call from him, disoriented at being forced to sit in the back of the bus due to the region’s racial segregation. He went on to get an education and become a decorated major. Indeed, it was he whom the US Army had chosen one year to explain the country’s mission during the Vietnam War. For months I felt iffy about a World War II-era Burberry coat I bought that was owned by Lt. Gen. William H. Stratton. Which is to say I couldn’t settle, comfortably, into a dead white man’s garment without a new mentality. I needed to shed the coat of its old power and summon a new authority. Turns out, I’m two generations removed from it.

title: The 18 Most Expensive Sneakers Ever Sold
article_text: In July 2019, the paradigm for the most expensivesneakersever sold shifted forever. That's when Sotheby's registered its first-ever sale of a pair of sports shoes at auction: vintage Nike “Moon Shoes” from 1972, which hammered for a record-setting $437,000—nearly triple the expected sale price of $150,000. Less than a year later, in May 2020, the auction house moved a pair of autographedAir Jordan1s for an eye-watering $560,000, making it clear that this was not a one-off fluke. “Loco prices like these are not just a high-water mark for collectors,” the Sneaker Freaker editor-in-chief Woody writes inTheWorld’s Greatest Sneaker Collections. “They also represent an influx of moneyed investors looking at sneakers as blue-chip investments.” In the sake of these legitimized auction-house trades, private sales of rare sneakers have exploded on the market, reaching some truly dizzying heights. “Today, both prices perversely look like bargains,” Woody writes of those first two sneaker sales, “if you can stomach the idea of old sports shoes worth as much as a house.” It seems all but guaranteed that these numbers will only continue to rise from here, so watch this space—the age of the sneaker auction is only just beginning. From more rare game-worn grails to insane one-of-one gems, here are the most expensive sneakers ever sold. Earlier this year, Sotheby's registered the most lucrative sneaker sale in the history of the auction house, when the eight-shoe pack known as the “Dynasty Collection” racked up an impressive $8 million sale. The Dynasty Collection included eight sneakers actually worn by Michael Jordan during the NBA playoffs across eight different seasons. Tim Hallam, the public relations officer for the Chicago Bulls for many years, asked MJ for one of his game-worn shoes after the Finals in 1991—a practice Jordan continued after every playoffs performance thereafter, perhaps out of superstition. These eight shoes represent theothersneaker that Hallam did not receive in these cases. What’s especially impressive about this sale is that none of the sneakers came in pairs. The lot also included a set of signed photos by Bill Smith of Jordan following each of the Finals, in which he can be seen wearing a shoe on just one foot. After the runaway success of ESPN’sJordan documentaryThe Last Dancein 2020, interest in Air Jordan sneakers worn during MJ's final season with the Chicago Bulls surged. Last year, a buyer completed a sale at Sotheby's for an ultra-rare pair of Jordan 13s that were on His Airness's feet for the iconic final game of the 1998 NBA Finals. The grand total?A staggering $2.2 million, negotiated in advance and in line with estimates from the auction house.It was a landmark sale for a single pair of sports shoes and a reminder that when it comes to sports memorabilia, it’s hard to beat Michael Jordan. The kicks were in the “Bred” colorway and appeared to be in good condition, especially considering they saw some serious action on the hardwood. LA-based conceptual artist Matt Senna is known for his resin sculptures made to look like classic sneakers, which he creates in small batches and sells off for $450 a pair. In 2020, however, took the concept one step further by crafting an Air Jordan 10 out of solid 24-karat gold. The one-of-one work of art was commissioned by Drake (who else?), and while they’re not actually wearable—each shoe clocks in at a hefty 100 pounds—they nonetheless belong on this list for their sheer audacity alone. Of course, it’s not just Jordans making noise on the high-end sneaker market, as this monumental sale proved. In the spring of 2021, Sotheby's registered a sale at auction of a one-of-a-kind pair of Nike Air Yeezy prototypes, which Kanye West debuted onstage at the Grammys in 2008. The sneakers were the first-ever pair sold for more than a million dollars. The Yeezys were purchased by the investing platform RARES. The company’s CEO and founder, Gerome Sapp, told the press that the shoes were acquired “in order to increase accessibility and empower the communities that birthed sneaker culture with the tools to gain financial freedom,” adding that buying them was like securing “a piece of history.” When this pair of Nike Air Ships sold for nearly $1.5 million at auction via Sotheby’s in late 2021, they briefly became the most expensive sports shoes of all time and remain one of the most expensive pieces of sports memorabilia ever sold. Worn by Michael Jordan during his fifth-ever NBA game in November 1984, they are a definitive part of sneaker history. Serious sneaker fans know the Air Ship as the first model Jordan sported in the league, while the design for the Air Jordan was still being finalized by Nike. This particular pair of Air Ships would have been one of the first and only shoes Michael ever wore on the court that weren’t part of his signature shoe line, making them in some ways even more special. Following Game 5 of the 1998 NBA Finals, a Utah Jazz ball boy by the name of Preston Truman was given a once-in-a-lifetime gift: the sneakers Michael Jordan wore during the game. In 2020, in the wake of the release ofThe Last Danceand the uptick in collectors’ interest in Air Jordans, Truman sold the shoes to Grey Flannel Auctions for a little over $200,000. Just three years later, in early 2023, they sold again at auction for an incredible $1.38 million. It helped that the shoes were worn during the legendary Flu Game, in which Jordan overcame a debilitating bout of food poisoning to deliver one of his most clutch performances ever. To this day, the black-and-red Air Jordan 12s are known as the “Flu Game,” which means that these sneakers are the OG version of one of the most beloved Jordan colorways of all time, too. Few game-worn sneakers have as much illustrious history attached to them. The story does have a down side:Truman launched a lawsuit against Grey Flannel in 2023, claiming that they pressured him into selling the shoes. The lawsuit is still ongoing. In August 2020, as post-Last DanceJordan hype was reaching record levels, a single pair of game-worn Air Jordan 1s turned heads when it sold atauction via Christie’s for more than half a million dollars. Worn by Michael Jordan during an exhibition game in Italy, according to the auction listing, they were actually estimated to fetch an even higher figure, closer to $850,000. (Still, the price was impressive.) What made this particular pair of Jordan 1s so unique was what else was included with them: a shard of broken glass, embedded directly into the shoe and apparently caused by Jordan shattering the backboard during a slam dunk. (These, of course, are not to be confused with the “Shattered Backboard” Jordan 1s.) During the same auction, a pair of sneakers worn by Jordan during Team USA’s gold medal game at the 1992 Olympics fetched over $100,000. On April 12, 2013,Kobe Bryantdelivered one of the most unforgettable performances of his career: despite tearing his achilles tendon mid-game, he managed to drop 32 points on the Golden State Warriors—even remaining on the court after the injury to drill two clutch free throws on one foot. It remains perhaps the finest example of Kobe’s famed “Mamba Mentality.” No surprise, then, that in February 2025, Sotheby’s managed to fetch well over half a million dollars at auction for the purple-and-gold kicks he wore that night. Mere months before the previous entry, another pair of Air Jordan 1s hit the auction block and shattered the previous record for the sale of shoes, which was set in 2019 (see below). Signed by Michael Jordan, the shoes were worn during a game in his rookie season. Like MJ's vertical, the bids for the sneakers were downright explosive in the final hours of the 10-day auction,rocketing up by $300,000 to close at an incredible $560,000. In 1972, when Nike was still just a fledgling upstart, the company's co-founder and running guru Bill Bowerman cobbled together one of the Swoosh's first-ever performance shoes. Dubbed the “Moon Shoes”—because their waffle-tread soles left astronaut-like footprints in the dirt—only about a dozen pairs of these crude prototypes were made and handed out that year to competitors at the US Track & Field Olympic Trials in Eugene, Oregon. They eventually served as the inspiration for Nike's legendary Waffle Trainer, which launched in 1974. Forty-five years later, the sneakers made history all over again by becoming the first collectible sport shoes to be sold at auction by Christie's. The 2019 sale helped establish the precedent for the market, which continues to expand and grow even now. At the time, no one expected sneaker auctions to be quite so coveted: initial estimates placed the Moon Shoes at a conservative $160,000, but the pair hammered for nearly triple that. Canadian business Miles Nadal, who scooped up these mammoth grails in the auction, called them “a true historical artifact in sports history and pop culture.” The “Broken Foot” Air Jordan 1s are yet another historic pair of game-worn Js that absolutelysmashedthe initial estimate. They sold fora jaw-dropping $422,130, almost double the starting bid of $250,000in an auction at Leland's in January 2022. The shoes take their name from an infamous game between the Bulls and Golden State Warriors on October 29, 1985, during which Michael Jordan fractured a bone in his left foot. The injury would become career-defining for Jordan, derailing his second season and igniting the fire that drove him toward his first championship, as detailed in the ESPN documentaryThe Last Dance. Leland’s said it acquired the shoes from “a cosigner whose father was gifted the game-worn sneakers personally from Jordan at the time,”according to a report in Complex. The sneakers come in Jordan’s own slightly mismatched sizing: size 13 on the left, size 13 and a half on the right. In February 2022, just months after the tragic passing ofVirgil Abloh, Louis Vuitton auctioned off 200 pairs of the late visionary's most coveted sneaker designs: aNike Air Force 1entirely covered in LV's iconic monogram and Damier check. The auction at Sotheby's was organized in support of Abloh's acclaimed scholarship fund “Post-Modern,” which was founded to “support the education of academically promising students of Black, African American, or African descent.” Most of the pairs sold in the low six figures. This particular pair, a US size 5, sold for nearly 25 times the original auction estimate and for twice the price of the second-most expensive pair sold, a US size 5.5 that went for $176,400. Demand for Abloh’s work only continues to skyrocket, and it seems likely that other rarities bearing his signature will sell for increasingly high figures as time goes on. “Power laces! Alright!”There’s perhaps no more famous sneaker scene in movie history than Marty McFly slipping on his futuristic, auto-lacing Nike Air Mag kicks in 1989’sBack to the Future: Part II. After decades of lobbying from fans, Nike finally released the fictional sneakers to the public via two highly limited drops: first in 2011, without the power laces; and then again in 2016withthem. All of the proceeds from both launches went to the Michael J. Fox Foundation, which supports the search for a cure for Parkinson's disease. The 88 pairs of the 2016 version alone raised more than $6 million for the charity, including a single pair auction off at a gala for awhopping $200,000. On December 5, 2012, at 34 years and 104 days old, Kobe Bryant surpassed Wilt Chamberlain to become the youngest player ever to record his 30,000th point in the NBA. (That record has since been eclipsed by LeBron James, who managed the feat at 33 years and 24 days old.) The Nike Kobe 7 PEs he wore during that game were sold at auction for $200,000 in March 2025. Both shoes are autographed and inscribed by Bryant, and the package included an actual ticket and a DVD of the game. For sneakerheads of a certain age, there's no more covetable shoe than the Air Jordan 11 “Space Jam,” named for its appearance in the movie and worn by MJ during his post-baseball return to the NBA playoffs in 1995. And the rarest, most alluring version of the “Space Jam” is this deadstock sample created for the film and signed by Jordan himself. Dubbed the “MJ’s Secret Stuff” Jordan 11s, they sold at auction in 2021 for an impressive $176,000. In December 2024, a truly insane find hit the auction block: a signed pair of original, never-worn Air Jordan 1s. Technically billed as “player samples” from the first factory run of Jordans back in 1985, the sneakers were presented as a gift to the head of advertising at the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company from a sports marketing agent who represented Jordan during his rookie season. They remained unblemished in their original packaging for nearly 40 years, before fetching an impressive $80,000 at Sotheby’s. Not quite a game-worn grail, but an incredible piece of sneaker history nonetheless. Sotheby’s recently auctioned off one of the more unusual sneakers on the collector’s market: an ultra-rare pair of Omega sports shoes that had been offered as a freebie to Apple employees at a sales conference back in the 1990s. Apple’s cultural cache was at an all-time low at the time, with the iPod still to come and the success of the Mac a fading memory, but allegiance to the brand still ran deep. When the company made its unexpected resurgence in the 2000s to become the most dominant tech brand on the market, employee merch like these sneakers became must-have collector’s items—hence the impressive price tag of $50,000. The Los Angeles-based sneaker boutique Undefeated, founded in 2002 by Eddie Cruz, remains one of the most beloved retailers in the industry. In 2005, the shop collaborated with Jordan Brand to release an extremely limited edition pair of Air Jordan 4s: the “Undefeated 4s,” inspired by the look of military flight jackets and covered in olive nubuck. The shoes were limited to only 72 pairs, and they have come to be regarded as one of the rarest and most coveted collabs ever. Last December, a single pair of this collaboration was auctioned off for $50,000, a testament to the shoe’s ongoing legacy. (Keep your eyes peeled, though:the Undefeated 4s are rumored to be making a long-awaited returnsometime this summer.)

title: Kevin Hart and Ed Sheeran Know This Rolex Is the Ultimate Collector’s Piece
article_text: If you’re a super-collector these days—a true member of the Swiss-made cognoscenti—then you better have Rolex’s limited- and extremely special-edition“Le Mans” Daytonaon your wrist. Immediately upon its 2023 debut in white gold, this impossible-to-source chronograph shot to the top of the Most Wanted list of every collector from here to Hong Kong. Case in point: BothEd SheeranandKevin Hartsaw fit to wear theirs this week. Don’t know precisely whichDaytonawe’re referring to? Let’s restart our chronographs for a moment, winding the proverbial watch back to 2023… We thought Rolex had played its hand in early April of 2023 at Watches and Wonders with its“Emoji” Day-Date, “Celebration” Oyster Perpetual, and 1908. All of these would have been perfectly good headliner releases for the year! Little did we know that the pièce de résistance would come out one random day in June of that year. The“Le Mans” Daytona, made in celebration of 100 years of the famous 24-hour endurance race, was a bombshell. The design is inspired by vintage Daytona designs and bespeckled with tiny Easter eggs and broke the collective mind of the horological internet while sending collectors into an absolute tizzy. And if you thought it was tough to secure a $15K steel Daytona, try snagging one of these highly limited-production totems of Swiss-made beauty. With a retail price of $51,400, they were quickly trading on the secondary market for a cool quarter-milly. As quickly as the white-gold version (ref. 126529LN) entered the Rolex catalog, it just as swiftly exited stage left to make room for one inyellow gold. Either way, both watches feature the same notable quirks. Those details include 24-hour totalizer, rather than the traditional 12-hour counter, in reference to the race’s day-long run time. Speaking of the chronograph subdials, these are pure white (without contrasting rings) much like those on the vintage and highly collectible “reverse panda” models. Even more significantly, the typeface used within the small confines of the subregisters is based on the one found on the “exotic” dials used in so-called “Paul Newman” Daytonas. Those dials, made by Singer, were originally unpopular and languished on shelves. However, their association with actor and driver Paul Newman—whose ownreference 6239 hammered for nearly $18M back in 2017—saw their value skyrocket over the past several decades. But, wait, there’s more! Take a look at the “100” index on the watch’s tachymeter bezel and you’ll notice it’s in red to highlight the 100th anniversary of Le Mans. (It also matches the red “Daytona” text, a feature of current-production Daytonas but also a reference to vintage “Big Red” versions such as the beloved ref. 6263.) No doubt it’s this special model’s many little quirks that caught the eye of Sheeran, who wore his white gold version at the 2025 Time100 Gala this week, and Hart, who wore his yellow gold version while seated courtside at the Nuggets-Clippers game this week. And to be fair to these two gentlemen, this is a killer watch. Handsome and heavy, it’s the type piece that every Rolex is desperate to own.

title: 8 Omega Fans Pick Their Favorite Speedmasters Ever
article_text: All products featured on GQ are independently selected by our editors. However, we may receive compensation from retailers and/or from purchases of products through these links. This is an edition of the newsletterBox + Papers,Cam Wolf’s weekly deep dive into the world of watches.Sign up here. If you were to rank the most important individual Omega watches—not just the brand’s model families, as we did last week—variants of the legendary Speedmaster would make up a large majority of the list. The watch isn’t merely iconic because it went to the moon—it was groundbreaking long before then and, over the decades, it’s been adopted by rally clubs, design enthusiasts, and everyone in between. “It’s utilitarian without being cold,” says Cam Barr, founder and CEO of the vintage watch store Craft + Tailored, of the Speedy’s enduring appeal. “Elegant without trying too hard. And that balance—function meeting design in such an intentional, almost stubborn way—shows up in nearly every Speedmaster reference, no matter the era.” The Speedy’s sublime design isa major reason it’s such a powerhouse for Omega. The watch looks as great in classic stainless steel as it does in solid yellow gold. Few watches are versatile enough to help astronauts time engine burnsandhost Snoopy on the dial. Here, we asked several Omega-obsessed members of the Watch Illuminati to select their favorite Speedmasters ever. It’s important to note that this is not a list of thebestand/ormost importantSpeedmasters—there are some very important references missing, like the supersized bright-red Alaska Project; the “Ed White” ref. 105.003, worn during the first space walk conducted by an American; the CK2915, the first Speedy ever, in 1957; or the ST 105.003, the one tested by NASA that resulted in the model’s selection for space travel. Instead, the watches you’ll find below go beyond the established greats for quirkier, off-the-beaten-path versions from throughout the watch’s rich history. Courtesy Robert-Jan Broer “The Apollo XI 50th anniversary in 18K Moonshine gold is the perfect tribute to the original gold Moonwatch that was given to the NASA astronauts in 1969. It combines elements from the original model—the burgundy bezel, two faceted onyx hour markers, a solid-gold dial, and a bracelet that tapers to 14 mm at the clasp—with Omega’s modern 3861 coaxial movement, ceramic and gold tech, and Moonshine gold alloy. For me, it’s the best of both worlds!” Courtesy Ashley Budgen “My personal favorite was always the 2005 Limited Edition Gemini IV ref. SU 145.0229 with a metallic blue-and-white reverse panda dial. I bought it very cheaply and in a very weird way: in a hospital maternity ward while the seller’s wife was giving birth (and checking in on him repeatedly to ensure he sold it). Though I had a lot of Speedys—including a lot of 321s—I loved and wore this one 90% of the time, until I eventually sold it to help fund another vintage purchase. As a modern watch, I knew I could always get another Gemini IV, while I couldn’t replace a vintage piece as easily. Nobody really liked these and they languished unsold. Then, after a few of us spammed photos of them on social media, they blew up in price, so I sold for about a third of what they’re worth now and haven’t found the right replacement yet. Definitely a deep regret that I let it go, in hindsight.” Courtesy Matteo, Master of Speed “Without a doubt, the reference I love the most is the very first ‘Professional’ asymmetrical-lugs Speedmaster equipped with the Caliber 321. Today, I’m happy to share with you one of the first watches I bought around 15 years ago, a 105.012-63. It was one of my earliest purchases when I first entered the world of vintage Omega Speedmasters. “I came across this piece with the inscription ‘A.C.P.’ on the dial. At the time, there was very poor information about—just a few books, many of which contained inaccuracies. Over the years, through research, with the Omega Museum and fellow enthusiasts, it was discovered that 50 of these watches were ordered in 1964 by a prestigious rally club in Peru. “This piece truly embodies the racing essence of the Speedmaster—before it became the Moonwatch and before it was chosen by NASA.” Courtesy Sacha Davidoff “My favorite Speedmaster ever is the CK 2998-3 ‘Lollipop.’ I love the look of it. I’ve sold a bunch of them over the years but kept one for myself. They’re damn near impossible to find anymore.” Courtesy William Roberts “My favorite reference is the Omega Speedmaster 14512. This watch flew on Apollo 11 with Michael Collins but didn’t make it to the moon. Later, in Apollo 14, Alan Shepard took it to the surface. “At the time, I think, Speedmaster sales were falling, and Omega made an effort to raise interest or even shift unsold stock by adding some unusual parts. There is the Ultraman, with the orange hand, which was initially thought to be limited to 50 pieces. “Then came the black racing dial with red markers, and it is this execution that I like most. With only approximately 10 pieces [in existence], with another 10 non-Professional examples, this is the rarest production Speedmaster.” Courtesy Cam Barr “I've handled my fair share of Omega Speedmasters over the years—dozens, probably more—but even before doing this professionally, I knew I needed one in my collection. “It wasn’t the whole ‘first watch on the moon’ thing that drew me in, at least not at first. It was the design language. The Speedmaster just makes sense. It’s utilitarian without being cold. Elegant without trying too hard. And that balance—function meeting design in such an intentional, almost stubborn way—shows up in nearly every Speedmaster reference, no matter the era. That’s what pulled me in. “Sure, the fact that it passed NASA’s insane testing and ended up strapped to the wrists of astronauts walking on the lunar surface? That’s a flex. But for me it's always been about how the Speedmaster wears, works, and looks on the wrist. “One of my favorite Speedies is actually a birth-year piece—something I don’t usually chase. But this particular 145.022 came through the shop, and it just ticked every box. It had that warm, golden tritium patina you see in a lot of the 1980s and early ’90s models. It’s got this glow that makes the whole watch feel alive and a bit different. Speedmasters from that era are still relatively attainable, but they offer history, wearability, design, and usually a striking patina. In my opinion, that is tough to beat. They’re the sleeper hits in the neo-vintage world.” Courtesy Phillips “Gold is good. That’s especially true when it comes to choosing my favorite Omega Speedmaster reference of all time. This conundrum was made easier by my affection for yellow gold, which took me to an obvious place: the BA145.022. “This reference is, of course, the Speedmaster created in the wake of the 1969 moon landing and the Apollo missions. Many of the watches were engraved with a message to the recipient—and those lucky owners included some pretty famous Apollo astronauts, like Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin, and Scott Carpenter. One was even presented to President Richard Nixon. He famously turned it down due to its high value, but the watch with his name engraved still exists. “I love this watch because it has such a weird little history. It was limited to just over 1,000 pieces and was given to all manner of folks—with some made available to the public. It’s a Speedmaster, but gold-er, with a gold case, bracelet, and dial. It has these very late-’60s-style black markers, and a dreamy burgundy bezel. This one was re-created by Omega in 2019, but my heart lies with the classic, the OG. This is the Moonwatch for those back on Earth, the Earthwatch. Maybe my adventureless spirit has something to do with my affection for this piece of Speedy lore.” Courtesy Anthony Marquié “During the research for ourMoonwatch Onlybook, we were fortunate enough to purchase and study many, many Speedies. In fact, the vast majority of the watches illustrated in this book were our own. It is very difficult to choose one reference from all those that have contributed to the history of this absolutely iconic watch. Among them, I could mention the first 2998s from the early 1960s, of course, or the solid gold Apollo XI model from 1969. “But this time, for emotional reasons, I'm going to choose my Speedmaster ‘Holy Grail’ ref. 376.0822, bought years ago from its first owner." (This was the first Moonwatch with an automatic movement and Omega produced fewer than 2,000 of this reference over just two years.) See all of our newsletters, includingBox + Papers,here.

title: The Real-Life Diet of Adam Pally, Who Might Scarf a Half-Eaten Sloppy Joe Left Outside a Hotel Room Door
article_text: Adam Pallywould like to make something clear: “I did not treat myself any worse than the normal person in their 20s and 30s who thinks they’re going tolive forever,” the now-43-year-old says. “Taking a look at your health is the last thing you really want to do. It's like, ‘Let me get health insurance before I go to the doctor.’” Now, rather than staying up all night and fighting off the impending hangover with more alcohol, Pally has found that a great night of sleep is often on the other side of a Postmates cheat meal. You can tell just from the names of two of his projects—the truTV show he once hosted with Jon Gabrus,101 Places to Party Before You Die, and now his new podcast with Gabrus,Staying Alive,which has a new episode every week—thatpersonal healthhas moved to the front of his brain. TheHappy EndingsandSonic the Hedgehogactor still loves to “throw down,” but as a celebration, not a retreat. In discussing his current state—somewhere betweenwellness kingand fun-loving dad—Pally mentions drinking condiments, the healing power of a hotel shower, and the logic behind “earning” your hangover. There’s a balance to everything, as one of his fitness mantras goes. Adam Pally:No, but the planwasto go to 101 places. We went to eight. For me and Jon, two of our parents died young. With that hanging over your head, there's also a positive to it, which is like you live life to the fullest, because you've experienced loss at a young age. The negative side of that is that sometimes you're not checking in with your body and seeing how long you can keep yourself around. I would say that's where the title came from. But again, you hit an age where death doesn't sound as romantic anymore. When you lose a parent, it's obviously horrible and hard and your world is shattered—if you had a good relationship with them. You have to figure out new things. But there's also a bit of a positive in it, which is freedom. You are in charge now, and I think in becoming in charge of oneself, you start to really take agency [as in], "Well, if I'm in charge, I want to stick around." Pally and Gabrus in 2022. Absolutely not. Look at me. No, man. Look how fat my face is. I literally dranksoy saucelast night. I do my best. I think one of the things I've learned in the podcast—and through tons of therapy—is that life is about balance. You can't even feel the highs and lows if you're not balanced most of the time. So, I try to be balanced. It can't all be one way. I think the only thing in life I'm obsessed with is myself. I just hadn't had sushi in a while. In our house we're trying not to order in as much, just because we want to cook more. All the things that my generation—I don't even know what we are—try to say and do to make ourselves feel better about our carbon footprint. But last night I got to eat by myself late. The kids had eaten, and so I did one of thoseThe Rock-style cheat meals of sushi where they bring you five chopsticks but it’s for one person. It was nice to do. I haven't done that in a while, and Islept great. I slept like a boa constrictor digesting a mouse. App dining is so different. You have your places that you love. That's it. That's where you app dine from. You're not like, super adventurous. I've never been to the sushi spot before, but when I click it, Postmates should have my order. Everything’s a balance. Is it great? No. But do those people order from Amazon? You can’t pull a thread on everything. Just try to do the best you can to stay alive. I think maybe my cardiologist would say, “There's things that should make you shudder,” but I don't feel that way. I just feel like I am lucky. I have a lot of friends that didn't make it out of their 20s and 30s. I'm really lucky to be here at 43 talking about how I can make it one more day. That feels...I never imagined that. I feel very fortunate for that. So, nothing really makes me cringe. I don't think anything like that. I just think that I'm lucky. But, look. A lot of it’s well-documented. I went to theUniversity of Arizona. I was insane. That’s okay too. But I feel lucky enough now at 43 to be like, “Okay. Let's get it together.” Usually you get introduced to that [on the] first day. You're like, I don't need to—it's not something you go back to. It's a one-time experience. Violently high sounds like Tucson, Arizona. It is one of the greatest places. If you want to talk about smoking mushrooms and going camping, I highly suggest Tucson, Arizona. Sure, sure. Atherapistwould say, “You are lying to yourself.” But yes, I think an outlet is good. I think a lot of times the thing that we are susceptible to with longevity coaches and wellness and all these things is that they let you not focus on the here and now in front of you. They prolong it and say, if you do this thing down the road, you will get better. Most of the time that's not true. Usually what's ailing people is money or health, and a lot of times that's out of your control. I feel pretty good. For a 43-year-old, I feel like I'm in good shape. I feel like I've gotten in better shape over the year. Last year I was in a writers’ room and on set for more days than I wasn't. Especially when you're shooting in Chicago and writing in Chicago, it's very easy. A PA [production assistant] will come around and be like, “You want a Polish sausage? Want a pierogi? Feeling low? I can put some boiled ones on there for you.” At 4 in the morning doing a night shoot? Yeah I’ll have a couple pierogi. I don’t know the next time I’ll be eating at a pierogi bar. Exactly. And it’s Chicago, so you go to the bar when you’re done. But I feel pretty good. I’m a year older than my grandfather was when he died. Last year, if you'd asked me how I feel, I would've been like, "I'm not doing great. I have this impending doom feeling." Today, I feel pretty good despite the state of everything being so horrendous. My diet's pretty good. I'm getting good exercise. Family's good. I feel pretty good. I’ll give you one from each region. In New York, White Castle. White Castle is great because you feel like a giant. You can pitch me a movie.
